utterances: Okay, a demo tape - normally in hip-hop, the way people were getting major deals was, they would take your demo tape to the record label and say, please, listen to my demo and, you know, the A&Rs and the executives will listen to it and say, okay, I'll give you a deal and then we can put out an album.

You know, a lot of that was changing in the new millennium but 50 Cent pretty much crushed it because here's a hip-hop artist that created a whole movement behind him from what he did in the mixtapes.
So he didn't go to any record labels and say, here, listen to my demo.
He made his music, gave it to the streets, and the streets already made him a superstar.

I think people have been pretty excited about natural gas because of this shale gas that people are finding, where you essentially - you've got gas locked up in these rock formations, and then you put water under pressure down there.
It cracks the rocks apart, and the gas can escape.

So after that, you know, our artists couldn't go to the record label and say, here's my demo because the record labels are saying, well, what do you got going on in the streets, where's your movement, where's your hometown and are they loving you, you know what I'm saying?
Are you getting that support from the streets already?
Now you are someone who, again, is very prominent in this whole scene because of the legal issues that you face right now.
Someone named DJ Doo Wop who is a longtime mixtape veteran has…
A legend.
A legend.
Has actually done a song ""2 of America's Most Wanted."" Let's take a listen.
(Soundbite of song, 2 of Amerikaz Most Wanted."")
Tell me if I (Unintelligible), me and my man slap and (unintelligible) until there's no end of you.
With the South Carolina film crew, when the boys rolled out, waving the things like nobody move.
Can you imagine what my mind was going through?
Not me, I ain't perfect but I ain't committing no murder…
Tell me what that's about.
That song right there is basically him taking the perspective of speaking for me during the raid on January 16th and, you know, what I was going through and, you know, I'm talking to the people.
So where from here in terms of the legal sense and the creative sense?
Well, legally, you know, I've yet to be indicted.
I've - myself and Don Cannon, we have yet to see a day of court.
You know, the case is not over.
I guess, it was to say it's still pending at this point so, you know, I'm hoping for the best.
But, you know, I have to admit our positives have outweighed my negatives.
I mean, I've been on the cover of numerous magazines.
I've been to Japan, Tokyo and Europe, and I've been about 35, 36 states since the raid so, you know, in an ironic kind of way, you know, I might have to say thank you.
Well, DJ Drama, thank you so much.
I appreciate it.
DJ Drama is a mixtape artist based in Atlanta.
He produces the ""Gangsta Grillz"" series and also as the tour DJ for rap star, T.I.
He spoke with us from Georgia Public Radio.
Dakota Staton, a jazz singer with a soulful edge, died two weeks ago today.
She was 76.
Staton grew up in Pittsburg.
As a teen, she performed in clubs in Detroit, Chicago and Cincinnati then moved to New York City.
She was discovered at a jam session at Harlem's Baby Grand in 1954.
The next year, she won Down Beat magazine's new star award.
In 1957, her first L.P., ""The Late, Late Show,"" introduced her to wider audiences going to number four on the album charts.
(Soundbite of song ""The Late Late Show"")
(Singing) Gee, it's cozy in the park tonight.
When you cuddle up and hold me tight, stars above they seem to know we're putting on The Late, Late Show.
Longtime jazz DJ Scott Willis.
She brought a bluesiness(ph) to the stage.
And she brought, kind of, a sassiness to the stage and to her performances that made her popular in the jazz world but also in popular music.
Staton never had another big album perhaps because of her quirky personality or her conversion to Islam.
Music writers say she also had a lot of competition from greats like Dinah Washington, Sarah Vaughn and Ella Fitzgerald.
Regardless of what the general public thought of her, Staton was wildly admired by other singers for her style.
Again, jazz DJ Scott Willis…
And her voice got, sort of, deeper and darker and more burnished as she continued but, you know, it's about energy.
It's about reaching an audience.
It's about appealing to people.
And, I think, she continued that for decades.
(Soundbite of song ""Someone to Watch Over Me"")
(Singing) Someone to watch over me.
Staton passed away at a geriatric center near her home in New York City.
(Soundbite of song ""Someone to Watch Over Me"")
(Singing) Although he may not be the man some girls think of as handsome, to my heart he carries the key.
That's out show for today and thank you for sharing your time with us.
To listen to the show, visit npr.org.
